// ENG2003 Portfolio Website â€” Full Content with Reflections, Showcase, and LinkedIn Integration import { motion } from 'framer-motion'; import { useEffect, useState } from 'react'; import './Portfolio.css'; export default function Portfolio() { const [showScrollTop, setShowScrollTop] = useState(false); const [activeModal, setActiveModal] = useState(null); useEffect(() => { const onScroll = () => setShowScrollTop(window.scrollY > 300); window.addEventListener('scroll', onScroll); return () => window.removeEventListener('scroll', onScroll); }, []); const scrollToTop = () => window.scrollTo({ top: 0, behavior: 'smooth' }); return (
{/* LinkedIn Banner */}

ENG2003 Communication Portfolio

Visit my LinkedIn
{/* Showcase Section */}

Showcase

{/* Showcase 1 */}

Showcase 1 â€“ Technical Report (ENG2003)

Why this piece? It demonstrated my ability to communicate complex engineering concepts clearly to non-technical audiences.

Communication development: It improved my structuring of technical documents and my ability to use visuals effectively.

Comfort zone? Yes, because I needed to simplify jargon-heavy content.

Best work? Yes, because it effectively blends clarity and detail.

{/* Showcase 2 */}

Showcase 2 â€“ Infographic Presentation (ENG2003)

Why this piece? It allowed me to apply visual design principles to technical communication.

Communication development: Helped me refine concise communication and data visualization.

Comfort zone? No, because I enjoy visual mediums.

Best work? Arguably, because itâ€™s accessible and engaging.

{/* Showcase 3 */}

Showcase 3 â€“ Email & Memo Assignment (ENG2003)

Why this piece? It helped refine my real-world business communication skills.

Communication development: I became more aware of tone, clarity, and professionalism.

Comfort zone? Yes, though I had to pay more attention to conciseness.

Best work? Not necessarily, but it was a strong exercise in applied communication.

{/* Showcase 4 */}

Showcase 4 â€“ Hackathon Pitch (External)

Why this piece? Itâ€™s an example of technical communication under time pressure.

Communication development: I had to synthesize a lot of information quickly and persuasively.

Comfort zone? Somewhat, but public speaking added challenge.

Best work? Yesâ€”it was practical, persuasive, and won our team recognition.

{/* Reflection Section */}

Reflection

Part A â€“ ENG2003 Course Reflection

ENG2003 exceeded my expectations. I initially thought it would focus solely on grammar and formatting, but it turned out to be a much broader and more dynamic experience in professional engineering communication. The technical report assignment taught me how to translate complex ideas into readable, purposeful documents. I especially appreciated learning the 7 Câ€™s and how to integrate them into real-world communication tasks.

The infographic project stood out because it required both design and data clarity. I realized how important visuals are in making information digestible. I also enjoyed the in-class simulations, like the mock interviews, which challenged me to communicate under pressure. These examples made the course feel applicable to industry scenarios.

Part B â€“ Communication Development

Prior to ENG2003, I would describe my communication style as verbose and overly technical. This course helped me develop clarity, purpose, and structure. My greatest improvement came in technical writingâ€”organizing sections for coherence and using headers, figures, and precise language effectively. Presentation skills also improved, especially in tone and pace.

I still need to refine my oral communication, particularly impromptu speaking. I plan to practice with recorded sessions and seek feedback more frequently. ENG2003 has reshaped how I approach group projects and technical documents in other coursesâ€”I now consider the audience more carefully and emphasize usability and clarity.

{/* Uniquely Tailored Section */}

Passion Projects & Interests

MTG Win Tracker (EDH Elo System)

This is a web app I built to track Commander deck performance using Flask, MySQL, and Elo rating logic. It taught me full-stack development, user interface design, and version control via GitHub.
